1.04.text:
Alice: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English.
I'm Alice.

5.22.text: Now, Alice, what did you get up to at the weekend?

7.32.text: Alice: Oh, I did some spring-cleaning,

10.00.text: which means cleaning a place very well, especially places you don't clean often.

14.92.text:
So, I was tidying up my wardrobe, trying to
organise things

18.92.text: and suddenly hundreds of shoes tumbled on my head!

22.14.text:
Rob: Poor Alice! But why do you have so many
shoes?

25.64.text:
And why do you keep them at the top of your
wardrobe?

29.60.text: Alice: I like to match my shoes to my outfit.

31.98.text: And three pairs wouldn't do the trick.

34.40.text:
Well, the subject of today's show is having
too much stuff.

38.64.text: And you're making me feel guilty, Rob.

40.92.text: You must have too much of something.

45.92.text: but they're getting out of hand ... and that means not under control.

51.21.text:
Alice: You can recycle plastic bags, you know,
Rob?

53.98.text:
Rob: Well, you can recycle shoes too, you
know, Alice!

57.78.text:
Rob: Now, usually I don't have a lot of clutter
in my flat.

61.28.text: And that means an untidy collection of objects.

64.06.text:
Clutter makes it harder to find the things
you need.

67.32.text: And it makes moving house a nightmare!

69.84.text: All those boxes full of things you don't need.

72.70.text:
Alice: Good point. I have a friend who suggested
the three buckets system.

77.54.text: You sort things into three different buckets:

80.44.text:
One you label as 'to keep', one as 'to get
rid of', one as 'maybe to get rid of'.

88.38.text:
Get rid of, by the way, means to remove something
you don't want.

92.36.text: It's the 'maybe' bucket that's tricky, isn't it?

94.98.text:
You never know if you might need something
in the future.

97.50.text:
Rob: Yes, it would need to be a big bucket
too.

100.38.text:
Rob: Well, l think we could all live better
with less.

103.88.text:
OK, well, let's have today's quiz question
before we talk more about de-cluttering our lives:

109.24.text:
So which word, Alice, means a belief that
physical possessions

113.42.text: are the most important thing in life?

115.70.text: Is it... a) metaphysics? b) materialism?

122.07.text: Alice: Um...OK... I think it's b) materialism.

128.08.text:
Rob: OK. Well, we'll find out if you got the
answer right or wrong later on in the show.

133.44.text: Now let's listen to Bea Johnson,

138.05.text: talking about how she and her family have adopted a minimalist

142.22.text:
Or deliberately simple lifestyle in their
California home.

147.48.text:
Bea Johnson: We've really asked ourselves
'what is it that we really need?'

150.70.text:
We've asked really true questions, and evaluated
every single thing that we have.

156.16.text: There is nothing that we overlooked.

158.83.text:
I even came to one day look at my vegetable
peeler for example and asked myself,

165.35.text: 'Do I really need that vegetable peeler'?

170.14.text: Rob: So one day Bea Johnson decided to evaluate,

173.56.text: or to judge the importance of something, to see if she needed it.

177.44.text:
Alice: She evaluated her vegetable peeler
and decided to put it in the 'get rid of' bucket!

183.59.text:
Rob: Yes, and to overlook something means
not to see it.

187.46.text:
Now, I don't blame Bea at all because I don't
like peeling vegetables either.

192.00.text:
And you could actually get the benefit of
the vitamins and minerals by eating the skins.

197.88.text: Rob: We can really live with fewer things.

200.18.text:
But some people can't help looking for the
latest version of something or go for designer goods.

206.38.text:
Writer and journalist James Wallman warns
us about this.

210.46.text: He wonders how much stuff is too much.

214.74.text:
James Wallman: This thing about need is such
a dangerous term because what do you need?

219.78.text: And I'm not anti-stuff ... stuff is good.

222.16.text:
I'm anti too much stuff and I'm anti the wrong
stuff.

225.38.text: Don't go out and buy that labelled good

227.78.text: that you think is going to make people think somethingmore of you.

231.22.text: That's not going to make you happy.

234.88.text:
Rob: James Wallman there. Now, Alice, do you
buy labelled goods?

240.85.text: And labelled goods or products are the ones with a famous brand name, like Gucci, Dior, Prada etc.

248.95.text: But I do think James Wallman is right.

251.68.text:
Buying things just because other people have
them, for example, doesn't make us happy.

255.46.text:
Rob: Yeah, that's true, but as he says, not
everything is the wrong stuff.

260.29.text:
For example, I'm very fond of my large schoolboy
collection of superhero comics.

265.34.text: I might not need them, but they make me happy.

268.79.text: So what stuff makes you happy, Alice?

270.66.text:
Alice: Oh, well, I like my music CDs and my
books.

274.16.text:
Even though I've got the music on an mp3 player
and I don't often pull a book out from the bookcase.

279.16.text: Rob: They have sentimental value, don't they?

281.88.text:
Rob: And that means the importance of something
because of a personal

284.70.text: or emotional feeling that we attach to it.

287.22.text: Well, I sold all my music CDs online ages ago.

290.88.text:
Alice: That sounds like the sensible thing
to do.

293.58.text:
OK, I think it's time for the answer to today's
quiz question, Rob.

298.97.text: Which word means a belief that physical possessions are the most important thing in life?

304.20.text:
Is it... a) metaphysics, b) materialism or
c) existentialism?

313.82.text: Rob: And you were right, Alice! Well done!

316.14.text: The answer is indeed b) materialism.

318.87.text: This is the word used to refer to a desire

321.55.text: for material things and wealth and little or no interest in ethical values.

327.08.text:
Now, can we hear the words we learned today
please, Alice?

329.97.text: Alice: Yes, of course. They are:

352.92.text:
Rob: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute
English. Don't forget to join us again soon!
